content:
no tests with numsCount being 1 or 100.
no tests with output >20.
With those constraints it's possible that output can be as high as 101, but there's no tests for that. 
You need to cover all the edge cases always, otherwise it's gambling.
Good contribution tho, I like it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easily solvable

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easily solvable

Personally, I don't see the point in the 
loopline numsCount nums:int

My solution deleted it entirely.  Even if you do wish to include it, perhaps at least make it the singular noun num rather than the plural noun nums since it is in reference to an individual entry from the array.  With it plural, my first instinct when quickly reading was that it might have been an array rather than an int.

For what its worth, I golfed the code down to 84 bytes in javascript after a first pass and might be able to golf further if I change my approach, so it might be worth considering it for shortest mode instead if desired.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash puzzle/idea. I think it's actually very simple in execution - just check all integers from 1 to 101.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's an easy exercise, but be careful not to rush it and misunderstand the statement in the fatest. I find it interesting on this point.

It's an easy exercise, but be careful not to rush it and misunderstand the statement in the fatest. I find it interesting on this point. I think it's still accessible for reverse play, but if in doubt I'd rather validate the clash without this game mode.

I really like this Clash.
Nevertheless there are some changes to make.
I'm not sure that it is easy to solve in reverse mode but it still can be solve.
The idea is good and I will sure approve it in a few days when 5DN1L will tell you all the changes to make.
Have a nice day.
Good clash puzzle/idea. I think it's actually very simple in execution - just check all integers from 1 to 1001. Just make sure to sort out the formatting issues mentioned by others.

Hi! I like the idea :) Simple in explanation, but not TOO simple in execution, as all clashes should be.

(5DN1L is much better at me than this, and will probably be here soon with more insightful info, but I thought I'd try and help :] )


Couple of suggestions so that it matches the format of most other clashes:

*Goal
I think you'll want to specify what you mean by "missing from the array". Saying something like "Counting up from 1, what number's missing". This might help comprehension when reading the clash quickly.

* Input
Please specify that the array is "A single unsorted array of space-separated integers"

You'll want to format 'nums' as a variable by placing "[[]]" on either side, like this [[nums]], wherever it's mentioned. This helps clashers know that it's a variable, and allows them to quickly skim, read, and comprehend your clash.

Please move "(1<= | nums | <= 1000)"  to "Constraints".
Also, since you mention that it can be both positive and negative integers, you'll want to extend your range. Looking at the test cases, I'd personally format it like this:
-100 <= [[nums]] <= 100.

I also believe that the second sentence would fit better in the Goal, but I don't think it's an issue leaving it there. 

In the input, you'll want to include every variable given to the clasher. Including the count variable. So, it'd look a bit like this:
<<Line 1>>: [[numsCount]] an integer.
<<Line 2>>: [[nums]] An string of space-separated integers of [[count]] length.

*Output
You'll want to make sure that nums has the variable markers here as well.

*Test Cases:
You'll want your test cases to be different from the validators. They need to be slightly different to avoid hard-coded solutions from working based on whatever the input is.
They should be similar, but slightly different with differing outputs.

I hope this helps! I'm still learning as well, so some of the information I gave may be slightly wrong, and I'm sure someone can help by correcting me ;P



Side note---
I think this clash would be good for Shortest, if you'd like to add that to the game modes.
If you include some more test cases early on that cover differing possibilities, then reverse could also work for this clash.

Thanks!

Input
* Please rewrite as follows to match the actual input format:
<<Line 1>>: An integer [[numsCount]] for the length of the array.
<<Line 2>>: An unsorted array of [[numsCount]] space-separated integers.

Constraints
* Please add the following:
1 ≤ [[numsCount]] ≤ 100
-100 ≤ an integer in the array ≤ 100

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar but different. Please revise the cases accordingly.

Thanks.
Already corrected!!! Thanks
Take care of the inequality sign! The second one should be <=. I've left a private message for @Killet on the forum to explain further.
Thank u so much :)
Thanks, I'll change it
mmm it may be a little difficult to reverse mode at first, I'll change it better. Thank you very much for your input
I changed it, thanks!!

Hello, thank you very much for your message! I'm new to this, your advice has helped me! In the case of specifying that they start from one, I think it is already clear by mentioning "find and return the smallest positive integer "

No problem! Glad I could help :)

It's looking great! 

In addition to what @5DN1L mentioned in his reply, all you need to do now is add some more test cases for Reverse, and make sure that your "Validator" test cases are different from the normal ones. They need to be similar, but with different outputs to avoid hard coded solutions. I'm not 100% that it would be a good fit for reverse, but I think with more test cases, it'd be fine. Others will be able to come to a more concise conclusion than I on this specific point.

Thank you, and please further follow up as follows:

Input
* Please delete "A single unsorted array of space-separated integers nums. The array may contain both positive and negative integers."

* Please move the following two lines to Constraints section:
1 ≤ numsCount ≤ 100
-100 ≤ an integer in the array ≤ 100

Thanks again.
done :)
